verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Standard introductory phrase, faithful to the Hebrew.

verses.text: "Make for yourself two silver trumpets; of hammered work you shall make them. And you shall use them for calling the congregation and for directing the movement of the camps."
verses.comment: Silver trumpets specifically refer to long, straight trumpets used in tabernacle service.

verses.text: "When both are blown, all the congregation shall gather before you at the entrance of the tent of meeting."
verses.comment: "Tent of meeting" is a traditional rendering of the tabernacle.

verses.text: "But if only one is blown, then the chiefs, the heads of the clans of Israel, shall gather before you."
verses.comment: Maintains word order and structure of the Hebrew.

verses.text: "When you blow an alarm, the camps that are on the east side shall set out."
verses.comment: “Alarm” translates the Hebrew word for a distinctive, sharper trumpet blast.

verses.text: "When you blow an alarm the second time, the camps that are on the south side shall set out. An alarm shall be blown whenever they are to set out."
"But when the assembly is to be gathered together, you shall blow, but you shall not sound an alarm."
verses.comment: "Blow" means a regular trumpet blast, as distinguished from an alarm.

verses.text: "The sons of Aaron, the priests, shall blow the trumpets. This shall be for you a perpetual statute throughout your generations."

"When you go to war in your land against an adversary who oppresses you, then you shall sound an alarm with the trumpets, so that you may be remembered before the LORD your God, and you shall be saved from your enemies."
verses.comment: ‘Be remembered before the LORD’ indicates a means of invoking God’s attention.

verses.text: "On the day of your gladness, and at your appointed feasts, and at the beginnings of your months, you shall blow the trumpets over your burnt offerings and over the sacrifices of your peace offerings. They shall be a reminder for you before your God: I am the LORD your God."
verses.comment: "Beginnings of your months" refers to the new moon.

verses.text: On the twentieth day of the second month, in the second year, the cloud was lifted from above the tabernacle of the testimony.
verses.comment: Tabernacle of testimony refers to the Tabernacle holding the tablets of the law.

verses.text: And the people of Israel set out by stages from the Wilderness of Sinai. And the cloud settled in the Wilderness of Paran.
So they set out for the first time at the command of the LORD by Moses.
verses.comment: Captures Hebrew's emphasis that this was the first departure since the law was given.

verses.text: The standard of the camp of the people of Judah set out first by their companies; and over their company was Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Issachar was Nethanel the son of Zuar.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Zebulun was Eliab the son of Helon.
And when the tabernacle was taken down, the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merari, who carried the tabernacle, set out.
verses.comment: Maintains close tie with original's order of march.

verses.text: And the standard of the camp of Reuben set out by their companies; and over their company was Elizur the son of Shedeur.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Simeon was Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Gad was Eliasaph the son of Deuel.
Then the Kohathites set out, carrying the sacred objects, and before their arrival the tabernacle was to be set up.
verses.comment: Emphasizes order in which Levite clans traveled.

verses.text: And the standard of the camp of the people of Ephraim set out by their companies; and over their company was Elishama the son of Ammihud.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Manasseh was Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Benjamin was Abidan the son of Gideoni.
Then the standard of the camp of the people of Dan, acting as the rear guard for all the camps, set out by their companies; and over their company was Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.
verses.comment: "Rear guard" translates the Hebrew phrase for "gatherer of all the camps".

verses.text: And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Asher was Pagiel the son of Ocran.
And over the company of the tribe of the sons of Naphtali was Ahira the son of Enan.
This was the order of march of the people of Israel by their companies when they set out.

And Moses said to Hobab the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law, "We are setting out for the place of which the LORD said, 'I will give it to you.' Come with us, and we will do good to you, for the LORD has promised good to Israel."
verses.comment: Some translations say ‘brother-in-law’ instead of ‘father-in-law’; here the relationship is clarified with reference to Reuel.

verses.text: But he said to him, "I will not go. I will return to my own land and to my relatives."
And Moses said, "Please do not leave us, because you know where we can camp in the wilderness, and you will serve as eyes for us."
verses.comment: "Serve as eyes for us" is an idiom meaning "act as a scout or guide."

verses.text: "And if you go with us, whatever good the LORD does for us, we will do the same for you."
So they set out from the mount of the LORD three days’ journey, and the ark of the covenant of the LORD went before them three days’ journey, to seek out a resting place for them.
verses.comment: "Mount of the LORD" refers to Mount Sinai here.

verses.text: And the cloud of the LORD was over them by day, when they set out from the camp.
And whenever the ark set out, Moses said, "Rise up, LORD, let Your enemies be scattered, and let those who hate You flee before You!"
verses.comment: This quote is perhaps poetic; alternately rendered "arise, O LORD!" Maintains original syntax.

verses.text: And when it rested, he said, "Return, O LORD, to the ten thousand thousands of Israel."
verses.comment: "Ten thousand thousands" translates the Hebrew idiom for an innumerable host.
